title: 108_s894
content: The Act is titled the "Marine Corps 230th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the Marine Corps. Congress finds that the United States Marine Corps, celebrating its 230th anniversary, has a long history of defending the nation and excelling in amphibious warfare. The Corps embodies a warrior ethos and its legacy should be commemorated for its significant contributions. The Marine Corps Heritage Center, authorized by Congress in 2001, is set to open on November 10, 2005. To honor the 230th anniversary of the Marine Corps, the United States should mint and issue a commemorative silver dollar coin. The Marine Corps Heritage Center, authorized by Congress in 2001, is set to open on November 10, 2005. To raise funding for its construction, a commemorative coin surcharge with no net costs to taxpayers is proposed. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint $1 silver coins with specific specifications. The coins will contain 90% silver and 10% copper, weigh 26.73 grams, and have a diameter of 1.500 inches. The silver for minting will be sourced from various available sources, including stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The coins minted will be legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the warrior ethos of the United States Marine Corps, with specific inscriptions and designations. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant entities and reviewed by a committee. The issuance of these coins will follow the designated specifications. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single designated facility for each quality, during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2005. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a $10 surcharge per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be paid to the Marine Corps Heritage Foundation for the construction of the Marine Corps Heritage Center. The Foundation will be audited for the amounts received. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a qualified institution is in place.
